name: Chapter 14: Connectivity to AWS
description: Flashcards explaining VPC-based networking services with metaphors and examples

cards.front: You’ve built your cloud infrastructure and want to isolate resources like EC2 and RDS while controlling access paths. What AWS service should you use?
cards.back: Use Amazon VPC (Virtual Private Cloud) to create an isolated network with subnets for specific functions and fine-grained control over access.
cards.example: You place web servers in a public subnet and databases in a private subnet inside your VPC.
cards.subject: AWS Cloud Essentials

glossary.definition: A logically isolated virtual network in AWS.
A range of IP addresses in your VPC used to group resources.

cards.front: You’ve launched a public-facing web app in your VPC but users can’t access it. What might be missing?
cards.back: You need to attach an Internet Gateway to your VPC to allow public internet access to resources in public subnets.
cards.example: A static website hosted on EC2 can't be reached until the VPC has an Internet Gateway.
cards.mnemonic: Internet Gateway = Entry to your cloud kitchen
cards.subject: AWS Cloud Essentials

glossary.definition: Enables public access to and from the VPC over the internet.

cards.front: Your company wants to access AWS resources securely from its on-premises network. Which setup should you use?
cards.back: Set up a VPN connection using a Virtual Private Gateway to create an encrypted tunnel from on-prem to your VPC.
cards.example: A corporate office securely connects to AWS using a VPN over the internet via a Virtual Private Gateway.
cards.subject: AWS Cloud Essentials

glossary.definition: An AWS endpoint for VPN connections.
A secure, encrypted connection over a public network.

cards.front: You need a fast, private connection between your on-premises data center and AWS—without using the public internet. What should you use?
cards.back: Use AWS Direct Connect to establish a private, dedicated connection between your on-premises infrastructure and AWS.
cards.example: An enterprise uses AWS Direct Connect to run latency-sensitive financial workloads.
cards.mnemonic: Direct Connect = Private hallway to the cloud
cards.subject: AWS Cloud Essentials

glossary.definition: Provides a private, dedicated network connection to AWS.

cards.front: You want instances in a private subnet to access the internet for updates, but not be accessible from the internet. What service should you use?
cards.back: Use a NAT Gateway to enable outbound internet access from private subnets while blocking inbound traffic.
cards.example: Your EC2 instances in a private subnet fetch OS updates through a NAT Gateway in a public subnet.
cards.mnemonic: NAT = Outbound only, keep it private
cards.subject: AWS Cloud Essentials

glossary.definition: Enables instances in a private subnet to access the internet without allowing inbound connections.

cards.front: Your app spans two VPCs and they need to communicate privately. What AWS feature allows this?
cards.back: Use VPC Peering to allow private, direct traffic between two VPCs using internal IP addresses.
cards.example: Two VPCs—one for analytics and another for ingestion—communicate using VPC Peering.
cards.subject: AWS Cloud Essentials

glossary.definition: Allows private communication between two VPCs without internet traffic.

cards.front: You're managing a multi-VPC environment and need a centralized way to route traffic across VPCs and on-prem networks. What should you use?
cards.back: Use AWS Transit Gateway to act as a central hub that connects multiple VPCs and on-prem networks efficiently.
cards.example: A large enterprise uses Transit Gateway to link 10+ VPCs and multiple on-prem locations in one place.
cards.subject: AWS Cloud Essentials

glossary.definition: A hub that simplifies connecting multiple VPCs and on-prem networks.

cards.front: You want to securely offer a service to another VPC without exposing it to the internet. What should you use?
cards.back: Use AWS PrivateLink to expose services to other VPCs using private IPs—without public internet exposure.
cards.example: A SaaS provider exposes an internal API to clients through AWS PrivateLink.
cards.mnemonic: PrivateLink = Service window, not a backdoor
cards.subject: AWS Cloud Essentials

glossary.definition: Provides private access to services across VPCs without public internet exposure.
